This paper was originally prepared as the Progress in Human Geography Lecture delivered at the Annual Conference of the Royal Geographical Society with the Institute of British Geographers, September 2011. An audio-record of the lecture was transcribed, and the author then revised that transcription into the paper published below. It was decided to allow some of the style of the spoken version to remain.

There is a mountain of secondary commentary on this book, in its various guises, upon which I draw at length in my own sustained discussion of MC, referencing too the original HF French version, in Philo (2004: 34–44 [and Notes on 65–72] and Chapter 8 [plus Notes]). In what follows, however, I will stick to close readings of the ‘primary’ texts, HF, MC and HM; and note that when I use these abbreviations, singularly or in variable combinations, I do so very precisely.

‘The geographical imagination’ was the theme of the Annual Conference of the Royal Geographical Society with the Institute of British Geographers, September 2011, as set by the Conference Chair (see Daniels, 2011).
This term, used for French armed resistance fighters, was itself a product of geography, referencing the type of thicketed, bushy high ground common in southeastern France, excellent for hiding.

Georges de La Tour and his works were rediscovered during the first four decades of the 20th century, leading to a Paris exhibition in 1934–1935, presumably when Char encountered this particular painting. Initially, it was interpreted as a young woman visiting a prisoner, but at this exhibition the favoured account was of an angel appearing to St Peter. Subsequently, however, the interpretation that has gained favour sees the scene as Job, afflicted in various ways for his sinfulness, being ‘interviewed’ or, more harshly, ‘reproached’ or even ‘scorned’ by his wife. Oddly, then, Char’s understanding of the painting, as a woman stooping to speak kindly to the ravaged prisoner in the depths of confinement, is contradicted by more recent readings (especially Nicolson and Wright, 1974: 32–33; Wright, 1977: 8) where the woman, Job’s wife, is thought to be adopting a more ‘hostile’ stance towards the man, Job. Intriguingly, Furness (1949: 54) anticipates this emerging interpretation, noting how certain representations had ‘transformed Job’s wife into an abusive and tormenting virago’, but he responds that ‘there is no trace of these in Georges de La Tour’s picture: rather, she seems half-pitying, half-impatient’.

The 1964 paperback edition lost Folie et Déraison from the cover, only showing the original subtitle, and its title page included the full original title but with the Folie component in smaller letters (Hacking, 2006: x). For Hacking, this loss of priority for ‘folly and unreason’ is instructive of bigger changes afoot in Foucault’s relationship to his own book, as will now be discussed in the main text. Insofar that HM endeavours to be the exact English ‘copy’ of HF, it is a little surprising that Folly and Unreason was not selected as the main title so as fully to mimic the original publication.

This very short preface – which Foucault concludes by noting that ‘[a]t least it’s short’ (HM: xxxix) – comments on the ‘doubles’ of the original book, by which he presumably means the many different readings of it, inevitably escaping from the ‘authority’ of the ‘author’. Hence, he has no wish to draft a new preface that attempts to take back control over how the book should be read; although, arguably, in various respects he tries to do exactly that in some later reflections on HF.

Hacking’s broader point is that the concern for unreason (indeed, Unreason) is increasingly stripped out of the book in later versions, so that it becomes more narrowly about madness; an observation of a piece with claims about the book losing its phenomenology and romanticism.

Foucault’s ‘Lives of infamous men’ essay originally from 1977 – seemingly intended as the introduction to anthology of archival fragments concerning internment in the Parisian Hôpital Général, the Bastille and other asylums/prisons – probably sheds further light on his method and motivations when preparing HF. He speaks of the documents that he consulted for ‘a book’ (surely HF) wherein official statements but also depositions from lowly, desperate citizens bring these otherwise entirely unknown (and unknowable) people into a twilight archival presence, offering a ‘minuscule history of [their] existences, of their misfortune, their wildness, or their dubious madness’ (Foucault, 2000: 159). The references here to ‘wildness’ and ‘madness’ are telling, but so too is Foucault’s acknowledgement that encountering the ‘stories’ of these unfortunates – the ‘oddball usurer’, the ‘sodomite monk’, the ‘caster of horoscopes’, the ‘debauched coachman’, these ‘loose women’ and more – ‘stirred more fibres within me that what is ordinarily called “literature”’ (Foucault, 2000: 158). I am indebted to Colin Gordon for cajoling me to read this essay.

In his ‘Lives’ essay (see note 9 above), Foucault explicitly reflects on the impossibility of doing justice to his ‘infamous’ prisoners and mad people. ‘The dream would have been to restore their intensity’, to recuperate the fine-grain and passions of their ‘lowly lives’, but Foucault (2000: 158) confesses that ‘the first intensities that had motivated me remained excluded. And since there was a good chance that they wouldn’t enter into the order of reasons at all, seeing that my discourse was incapable of conveying them in the necessary way, wouldn’t it be better to leave them in the very form that had caused me to first feel them?’ A melancholy ‘romantic’ gesture hence meets the more cautious scholar-theorist, nicely expressing certain struggles of the later Foucault that I detail more fully later in my main text.

It is here that the connection to the later ‘Lives’ essay becomes most apparent, given that the latter hinges precisely on how the ‘power’ of monarch and state (circulating through ‘mechanisms’ of, first, ‘pardoning’ and, later, ‘recording’) gathers up (and then presses upon) these fragmentary life-worlds as revealed in countless yellowing dossiers of (here Early Modern) internment. Nonetheless, the archived transcripts could still permit a glimpse of the disturbed ‘other’ beyond, leading Foucault (2000: 158) to reflect upon ‘the blend of dark stubbornness and rascality’ pervading ‘these lives whose disarray and relentless energy one senses beneath the smooth-stone words’.

Concluding his ‘Lives’ essay, Foucault (2000: 170, 174) suggests that the archived fragments of ‘lowly lives’ – although ‘upset by a vibration, by wild intensities muscling in their own ways of saying things’ – still cannot be taken as ‘even the first sketch of a genre’.

There are many things to discuss about Foucault’s views on psychoanalysis, which are for the most part highly critical, and the time is also ripe for an engagement between Foucauldian and psychoanalytic geographers. Such a discussion and engagement, with full referencing, must nonetheless await another occasion.

The image of the fortress is another powerful spatial referent throughout HF, clearly deriving in large measure from the fortress-like prison and then asylum to which the Marquis de Sade was consigned. At one point, Foucault (HM: 362) mentions ‘images of the Fortress, the Cell, the Dungeon, the Covent, the inaccessible Island that seem to be the natural places of unreason’. A fuller account of the book’s phenomenological geography would dwell longer on such spaces.
There are various other presences of Char in HF: passages where he is explicitly mentioned and quoted (e.g. HM: xxxv), but also ones where he is strangely unattributed (e.g. HM: 530).

Also known as the Partage des Eaux (Parting of the Waters), it is a spot where the River Sourge divides around the Isle sur la Sourge, while the river itself rises at the spring of Fontaine-de-Vaucluse in the department of Vaucluse in southeast France (supposedly such an inspiration for Char).
The source of this quote is Char’s Partage formel.

It is of course important to caution against too simplistic a binarizing of Enlightenment and Romanticism: indeed, ‘the old canonical construction of “Enlightenment” versus “Romanticism”, “Age of Johnson” versus “Age of Shelley, Wordsworth, Coleridge, Keats, Blake and Byron” potentially limits critical exchange’ (Wallace, 2009: 1). Accordingly, Wallace (2009) asks readers to contemplate ‘enlightened romanticism or romantic enlightenment?’.

There are accounts that trace how the Enlightenment, as a located historical phenomenon in the long-18th century of Europe and its overseas ‘possessions’, impacted upon contemporaneous and immediately subsequent geographical inquiry (e.g. Livingstone, 1992: Chapter 4; Livingstone and Withers, 1999; Mayhew, 2000; Withers, 2007). Similar accounts of Romanticism’s influence on the deeper history of geographical inquiry are perhaps less common (but see Tang, 2008; see also Squire, 1988, and reply by Sitwell, 1990; Wiley, 1998).

There has been a very recent outbreak of Spinozan discussion, prompted by Pile’s (2010) psychoanalytically turned critique of non-representational theory in human geography: see Curti et al., 2011; Dawney, 2011).
Other uses of the term ‘romantic geographies’ can be found in Gilroy (2000a), Smethurst (1996a) and Wiley (1998).

I emphasize this point because, while there might be an understandable sense that the present essay – and perhaps many of the matters discussed here – are locked in a somewhat ‘bookish’ arena, the impetus (the ethico-politics) that drives romantic geographies, whether early humanistic or more recent vitalist versions, does arise from wishing to effect changed ways of seeing and acting in/on the world. Notwithstanding what might be supposed from some critiques, such an imperative is not the preserve of a small cadre of critical-Marxian-activist geographers, many of whom, in any case, are arguably driven by much the same version of a ‘romantic’ (‘utopian’) wish to make the world over differently.
A close parallel to Geoghegan and Woodyer (2012), looking to bring ‘enchantment’ back into cultural and media studies, is Black (2009).

Tellingly, perhaps, ‘Gypsies …, bandits, social outcasts and sundry giaours [infidels] populate nearly all literary genres in the Romantic period’ (Smethurst, 1996b: viii–ix), thus indexing a certain affinity for ‘outsiders’ displayed by Romanticism as movement.

Many on the ‘Left’ have displayed greater sympathies with Romanticism: consider E.P. Thompson’s well-known calls for a ‘transformed romantic tradition’ (in Black, 2009: 1); while Geoghegan and Woodyer (2012) position so-called ‘Magical Marxism’ decisively on the side of ‘enchantment’.

I am inspired by the following quote from Alan Lui, distinguished Romanticist, and I hope that its message can travel from its original (relatively narrow) context, where ‘Romantic ideology’ refers to a particular envisaging of self-world relations and the immediate aim is to clarify how ‘new historicism’ (as a specific scholarly move within historical-literary inquiry) might respond to Romanticism: ‘What is to be hoped for, perhaps, is not the total banishment of “Romantic ideology” from our own criticism but a containment of such ideology as if in quotes … The goal of the new historicism should be conscious reflection upon its own illusions able to make use of them as part of a full-spectrumed historicist criticism – a method that spans from ironic distanciation to recognition, acknowledgement and sympathy’ (Lui, 1988: 179, in Davies, 2009: 6, emphasis in original). Making use of romantic ‘illusions’, but containing and reflecting upon them in a ‘full-spectrumed’ geographical criticism: that nicely encapsulates the delicately balanced position reached by my essay.
